<div class="pageHeader underline">
<div>United Wholesale Grocers Limited</div>
<div>Strategic Report</div>
<div><span>For The Year Ended 31 December 2023</span>
</div>
</div>
<div class="sectionName">Strategic Report</div>
<div id="p5_Strategic_Report">
<div>The directors present their strategic report for the year ended 31 December 2023.</div>
<div id="p5_5_3_Review_of_Business">
<div class="title">Review of the Business</div>
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>The company's performance in 2023 reflects solid growth and prudent financial management, with key highlights across both financial and non-financial metrics.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>
<span style=" font-weight:bold;">Financial Performance:</span>
</div>
<div class="blank-line" style="       font-weight:bold;"/>
<div>
<span style=" font-weight:bold;">Revenue Growth:</span> The company achieved a 3.81% increase in turnover, reaching £226.3 million, up from £218 million in 2022. This steady growth is attributed to effective product availability management, particularly through strategic stockpiling when shortages were anticipated, positively impacting sales performance.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>
<span style=" font-weight:bold;">Profitability:</span> Gross profit rose to £18.8 million, an increase of £1.9 million from the previous year, driven by improved purchasing discounts and a well-calibrated pricing and promotional strategy. Operating profit saw an even more pronounced rise, growing by 27.2% to £6.1 million from £4.8 million. This impressive growth is largely due to enhanced gross margins and disciplined cost management, keeping operating expenses below inflation levels.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>
<span style=" font-weight:bold;">Cash Reserves:</span> The company’s cash generation has been robust, with cash and cash equivalents increasing to £20.7 million from £19.1 million in 2022. This healthy liquidity positions the company strongly, providing financial flexibility and headroom for future investments and mitigating external economic uncertainties.The company's turnover increased by 3.81% to £226.3 million from £218 million in 2022.  We have continued to improve and manage availability of products during this period and where shortage was expected we carried higher level of stock, which resulted in the favourable impact on sales. </div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>
<span style=" font-weight:bold;">Non-Financial Performance</span>
</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>The company closely monitors key non-financial indicators such as customer satisfaction, staff turnover, and stakeholder relationships. These metrics are vital in maintaining a positive company culture, strong customer loyalty, and solid relationships with suppliers and other stakeholders. Regular feedback is gathered to continuously improve these areas. </div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
</div>
</div>
<div id="p5_5_principalRisksAndUncertainties">
<div class="title">Principal Risks and Uncertainties</div>
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>The Board has implemented internal controls to facilitate the identification, assessment and management of risk, as a reasonable assurance against adverse implications. The principal risks determined by the Board, corresponding controls and mitigation actions are set out below and is not in particular order of priority. This represents the company's current profile and is not intended to be an exhaustive list of risks and uncertainties that may arise. </div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>
<span style=" font-weight:bold;">Regulatory Compliance:</span> The business operates in a highly regulated environment, covering areas such as health and safety, employment law, and data protection. The board is vigilant about regulatory changes, regularly updating policies and ensuring relevant employee training to maintain compliance. Failure to do so could harm profitability and reputation.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>
<span style=" font-weight:bold;">Competition:</span> The wholesale industry remains intensely competitive, with pressure from both national retailers and regional independent wholesalers. The company competes effectively through a combination of competitive pricing, strong value propositions, and attractive promotions, ensuring it remains responsive to market shifts.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>
<span style=" font-weight:bold;">Post-Brexit Effects:</span> The company capitalized on Brexit by strategically holding higher stock levels, which bolstered sales. However, this benefit is unlikely to recur, and future profit margins may face pressure as the market adjusts to new conditions.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>
<span style=" font-weight:bold;">Interest Rate Fluctuations</span>: The company has benefited from the current high interest rates, but a potential reduction, as predicted, could impact profitability. Proactive financial planning will be necessary to mitigate this risk.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>
<span style=" font-weight:bold;">Supplier Relationships and Credit Risk</span>: Maintaining strong supplier relationships is critical to ensuring product availability. Any disruption in supply or reduction in supplier credit could adversely affect operations. The company mitigates this by closely managing supplier performance and maintaining diverse sourcing channels.</div>
</div>
<div class="continue">...CONTINUED</div>
<div class="pageElement" style="padding-top: 0px;">
<div class="break">
<div class="pagWebviewPageFooter">Page 1</div>
</div>
<div class="pagPrintPageFooter" style="top: 998.16px;">Page 2</div>
</div>
<div class="pageHeader underline">
<div>United Wholesale Grocers Limited</div>
<div>Strategic Report (continued)</div>
<div><span>For The Year Ended 31 December 2023</span>
</div>
</div>
<div class="title">Principal Risks and Uncertainties - continued</div>
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>
<span style=" font-weight:bold;"> Mitigation Strategies:</span>
</div>
<div class="blank-line" style="       font-weight:bold;"/>
<div>
<span style=" font-weight:bold;">Credit Risk Management:</span> The company conducts stringent credit checks on new customers and employs robust credit control procedures. Additionally, it secures guarantees or undertakings from customers to safeguard against defaults.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>
<span style=" font-weight:bold;">Operational Resilience:</span> IT systems are essential for business continuity, and the company has invested in comprehensive backup procedures, network security, and independent cybersecurity expertise. This mitigates risks related to system failures and cyber threats.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>
<span style=" font-weight:bold;">Health and Safety:</span> The company prioritizes workplace safety, ensuring compliance with regulatory standards to avoid incidents that could result in financial or reputational damage. Policies and procedures are regularly reviewed and enforced across the business.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div class="blank-line"/>
</div>
</div>
<div id="p5_5_4_Future_Developments">
<div class="title">Future Developments</div>
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>The company is well-positioned for future growth, with the directors intending to build on the strategies that have driven consistent performance. While inflationary pressures and broader economic uncertainties remain, the company’s strong cash reserves provide a solid foundation for investment in new sales outlets and other growth opportunities.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>The management team is aware of the challenges ahead, including competitive pressures and the normalization of post-COVID market dynamics, but remains confident in the resilience of the business model. Strategic investments and continued focus on operational efficiency will be crucial in driving sustainable growth. </div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>While we remain cautious about the current economic climate, we hope to demonstrate the strength of our business model with the continued support of our employees a successful relationship with our suppliers and customers.</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="pageElement" style="padding-top: 363.16px;">
<div class="break">
<div class="pagWebviewPageFooter">Page 2</div>
</div>
<div class="pagPrintPageFooter" style="top: 998.16px;">Page 3</div>
</div>
<div class="pageHeader underline">
<div>United Wholesale Grocers Limited</div>
<div>Strategic Report (continued)</div>
<div><span>For The Year Ended 31 December 2023</span>
</div>
</div>
<div class="unbreakable">
<div id="p5_5_section1721Statement">
<div class="title">Section 172(1) Statement</div>
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>The directors are committed to promote the success of the company, and in doing so, complying with their duties under Section 172 of the Companies Act 2006. In doing this, the directors have given careful considerations to the following factors: </div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>- the likely consequences of any decision in the long-terms; </div>
<div>- the interest of company's employees; </div>
<div>- the need to foster the company's relationship; </div>
<div>- the impact of the company's operations on the community and the environment; </div>
<div>- the desirability of the company's maintaining a reputation for high standards of business conduct: and </div>
<div>- the need to act fairly as between members of the company </div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>The directors have also considered the company's business activities to identify the company's key stakeholders, which includes the following: </div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>- Employees </div>
<div>- Shareholders </div>
<div>- Suppliers, insurers and contractors </div>
<div>- Customers </div>
<div>- Local communities and the environment </div>
<div>- Government and regulatory authorities </div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>The Board is committed to effective engagement with all of its stakeholders. The relevance of each stakeholder group may differ and, as such, as part of its engagement with stakeholders, the board understands the relative interests and priority of each relevant stakeholder group and have regard to these, as appropriate, in its decision making. The board acknowledges that not every decision it makes will necessarily result in a positive outcome for all stakeholder groups, however, they consider this as part of wider consideration of all stakeholder group for effective decision making. </div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>Every month, the Board and management team undertakes a review where they discuss the financial and strategic performance of the company and the impact of significant decisions taken in the period. The aim is to identify factors which would lead to any positive or negative impact, financial and non-financial, on the status of the company's stakeholders including its employees, shareholders, suppliers, customers, communities, the environment, regulators and the government. </div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>The Board and its management team regularly share reports on issues concerning employees, shareholders, customers, suppliers, insurance, contractors, communities, the environment, regulators and the government, which takes into account in its discussion and in its decision- making process under section 172. Also, the Board seeks to understand interests and views of the stakeholders and engage with them directly as appropriate. </div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>The risk management framework and principal risks and uncertainties are stated as set out above.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
</div>
</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>On behalf of the board</div>

<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>It is the company policy to involve employees in the business and to ensure that matters of concern to them, including company's aims and objectives and its financial performance, are communicated in an open and regular way and, when appropriate,employees' view are taken into account. </div>

<div>The promotion of equal opportunities for all employees, including disabled persons,is regarded as an important priority. <div class="title">Matters covered in the Strategic Report</div>
<span>

</div>
<div id="p5_5_1_Statement_of_Directors_Responsibilities">
<div class="title">Statement of Directors' Responsibilities</div>
<span>
<ix:nonNumeric contextRef="CURRENT_FY_PERIOD" name="frs-direp:StatementThatDirectorsAcknowledgeTheirResponsibilitiesUnderCompaniesAct">
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>The directors are responsible for preparing the Strategic Report, the Directors' Report and the financial statements in accordance with applicable law and regulations.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>Company law requires the directors to prepare financial statements for each financial year. Under that law the directors have elected to prepare the financial statements in accordance with United Kingdom Generally Accepted Accounting Practice (United Kingdom Accounting Standards, comprising FRS102 'The Financial Reporting Standard applicable in the UK and Republic of Ireland', and applicable law). Under company law the directors must not approve the financial statements unless they are satisfied that they give a true and fair view of the state of affairs of the company and of the profit or loss of the company for that period. In preparing the financial statements the directors are required to:</div>
<div>
<ul>
<li>select suitable accounting policies and then apply them consistently;</li>
<li>make judgments and accounting estimates that are reasonable and prudent;</li>
<li>state whether applicable United Kingdom Accounting Standards, comprising FRS102, have been followed subject to any material departures disclosed and explained in the financial statements;</li>
<li>prepare the financial statements on the going concern basis unless it is inappropriate to presume that the company will continue in business.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div>The directors are responsible for keeping adequate accounting records that are sufficient to show and explain the company's transactions and disclose with reasonable accuracy at any time the financial position of the company and enable them to ensure that the financial statements comply with the Companies Act 2006. They are also responsible for safeguarding the assets of the company and hence for taking reasonable steps for the prevention and detection of fraud and other irregularities.</div>
</div>
</ix:nonNumeric>
</span>
</div>
<div id="p5_5_1_ePublication">
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div> The directors are responsible for the maintenance and integrity of the corporate and financial information included on the company's website. Legislation in the United Kingdom governing the preparation and dissemination of financial statements may differ from legislation in other jurisdictions.</div>
</div>
</div>
<div id="p5_5_1a_Statement_of_disclosure_of_information_to_auditors">
<div class="title">Statement of Disclosure of Information to Auditors</div>
<span>
<ix:nonNumeric contextRef="CURRENT_FY_PERIOD" name="frs-direp:StatementOnQualityCompletenessInformationProvidedToAuditors">
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>In the case of each director in office at the date the Directors' Report is approved: <ul>
<li>so far as the director is aware, there is no relevant audit information of which the company's auditors are unaware; and</li>
<li>they have taken all the steps that they ought to have taken as directors in order to make themselves aware of any relevant audit information and to establish that the company's auditors are aware of that information.</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</ix:nonNumeric>
</span>
</div>

<div class="sectionName">Independent Auditor's Report</div>
<div id="p5_5_Auditors_Report">
<div class="unbreakable">
<div class="title" id="p5_5_Auditors_Report1">Opinion</div>
<ix:nonNumeric contextRef="CURRENT_FY_PERIOD" name="frs-aurep:OpinionAuditorsOnEntity">
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>We have audited the financial statements of <span>
<ix:nonNumeric contextRef="CURRENT_FY_PERIOD" name="frs-bus:EntityCurrentLegalOrRegisteredName">United Wholesale Grocers Limited</ix:nonNumeric>
</span> for the year ended 31 December 2023 which comprise the Statement of Comprehensive Income, Balance Sheet, Statement of Changes of Equity and the related notes, including a summary of significant accounting policies. The financial reporting framework that has been applied in their preparation is applicable law and United Kingdom Accounting Standards (United Kingdom Generally Accepted Accounting Practice), including FRS 102 "The Financial Reporting Standard applicable in the UK and Republic of Ireland".</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div> In our opinion the financial statements:</div>
<ul>
<li>give a true and fair view of the state of the company's affairs as at 31 December 2023 and of its profit/(loss) for the year then ended;</li>
<li>have been properly prepared in accordance with United Kingdom Generally Accepted Accounting Practice; and</li>
<li>have been prepared in accordance with the requirements of the Companies Act 2006.</li>
</ul>
</div>
</ix:nonNumeric>
</div>
<div class="unbreakable">
<div class="title" id="p5_5_Auditors_Report2">Basis for Opinion</div>
<ix:nonNumeric contextRef="CURRENT_FY_PERIOD" name="frs-aurep:BasisForOpinionAuditorsOnEntity">
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>We conducted our audit in accordance with International Standards on Auditing (UK) (ISAs (UK)) and applicable law. Our responsibilities under those standards are further described in the Auditor's responsibilities for the audit of the financial statements section of our report. We are independent of the company in accordance with the ethical requirements that are relevant  to  our  audit of the financial statements in the UK, including the FRC's Ethical Standard, and we have fulfilled our other ethical responsibilities in accordance with these requirements. We believe that the audit evidence we have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our opinion.</div>
</div>
</ix:nonNumeric>
</div>
<div class="unbreakable">
<div class="title" id="auditors_frs_ConclusionsRelatingToGoingConcern">Conclusions Relating to Going Concern</div>
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>In auditing the financial statements, we have concluded that the directors' use of the going concern basis of accounting in the preparation of the financial statements is appropriate.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>Based on the work we have performed, we have not identified any material uncertainties relating to events or conditions that, individually or collectively, may cast significant doubt on the entity's ability to continue as a going concern for a period of at least 12 months from when the financial statements are authorised for issue.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>Our responsibilities and the responsibilities of the directors with respect to going concern are described in the relevant sections of this report.</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="unbreakable">
<div class="title" id="p5_5_Auditors_Report7">Other Information</div>
<ix:nonNumeric contextRef="CURRENT_FY_PERIOD" name="frs-aurep:StatementAuditorsResponsibilitiesRelatingToOtherInformation">
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>The other information comprises the information included in the annual report, other than the financial statements and our auditor's report thereon. The directors are responsible for the other information contained within the annual report. Our opinion on the financial statements does not cover the other information and, except to the extent otherwise explicitly stated in our report, we do not express any form of assurance conclusion thereon. In connection with our audit of the financial statements, our responsibility is to read the other information and, in doing so, consider whether the other information is materially inconsistent with the financial statements or our knowledge obtained in the audit or otherwise appears to be materially misstated. If we identify such material inconsistencies or apparent material misstatements, we are required to determine whether this gives rise to a material misstatement in the financial statements themselves. If, based on the work we have performed, we conclude that there is a material misstatement of this other information, we are required to report that fact.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>We have nothing to report in this regard.</div>
</div>
</ix:nonNumeric>
</div>
<div class="pageElement" style="padding-top: 67.16px;">
<div class="break">
<div class="pagWebviewPageFooter">Page 7</div>
</div>
<div class="pagPrintPageFooter" style="top: 998.16px;">Page 8</div>
</div>
<div class="pageHeader underline">
<div>Independent Auditor's Report (continued) </div>

<div>United Wholesale Grocers Limited</div>
</div>
<div class="unbreakable">
<div class="title" id="p5_5_Auditors_Report5">Opinions on Other Matters Prescribed by the Companies Act 2006</div>
<ix:nonNumeric contextRef="CURRENT_FY_PERIOD" name="frs-aurep:OpinionAuditorsInRespectAdditionalFinancialReportingFramework">
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>In our opinion, based on the work undertaken in the course of the audit:</div>
<div>
<ul>
<li>the information given in the Strategic Report and Directors' Report for the financial year for which the financial statements are prepared is consistent with the financial statements; and</li>
<li>the Strategic Report and Directors' Report have been prepared in accordance with applicable legal requirements.</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</ix:nonNumeric>
</div>
<div class="unbreakable">
<div class="title" id="p5_5_Auditors_Report6">Matters on Which We Are Required to Report by Exception</div>
<ix:nonNumeric contextRef="CURRENT_FY_PERIOD" name="frs-aurep:StatementOnMattersOnWhichAuditorReportsByException">
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>In the light of the knowledge and understanding of the company and its environment obtained in the course of the audit, we have not identified material misstatements in the Strategic Report or the Directors' Report.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>We have nothing to report in respect of the following matters in relation to which the Companies Act 2006 requires us to report to you if, in our opinion:</div>
<div>
<ul>
<li>adequate accounting records have not been kept, or returns adequate for our audit have not been received from branches not visited by us; or</li>
<li>the financial statements are not in agreement with the accounting records or returns; or</li>
<li>certain disclosures of directors' remuneration specified by law are not made; or</li>
<li>we have not received all the information and explanations we require for our audit.</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</ix:nonNumeric>
</div>
<div class="unbreakable">
<div class="title" id="auditors_frs_ResponsibilitiesOfDirectors">Responsibilities of Directors</div>
<ix:nonNumeric contextRef="CURRENT_FY_PERIOD" name="frs-aurep:StatementOnRespectiveResponsibilitiesDirectorsAuditors">
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>As explained more fully in the Directors' Responsibilities Statement set out on page <span id="pageNO_p5_5_Directors_Report">4—6</span>, the directors are responsible for the preparation of the financial statements and for being satisfied that they give a true and fair view, and for such internal control as the directors determine is necessary to enable the preparation of financial statements that are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>In preparing the financial statements, the directors are responsible for assessing the company's ability to continue as a going concern, disclosing, as applicable, matters related to going concern and using the going concern basis of accounting unless the directors either intend to liquidate the company or to cease operations, or have no realistic alternative but to do so.</div>
</div>
</ix:nonNumeric>
</div>
<div class="pageElement" style="padding-top: 338.16px;">
<div class="break">
<div class="pagWebviewPageFooter">Page 8</div>
</div>
<div class="pagPrintPageFooter" style="top: 998.16px;">Page 9</div>
</div>
<div class="pageHeader underline">
<div>Independent Auditor's Report (continued) </div>
<div> to the Members of</div>
<div>United Wholesale Grocers Limited</div>
</div>
<div class="unbreakable">
<div class="title" id="auditors_frs_AuditorsResponsibilitiesForTheAuditOfTheFinancialStatements">Auditor's Responsibilities for the Audit of the Financial Statements</div>
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>Our objectives are to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements as a whole are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and to issue an auditor's report that includes our opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance but is not a guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with ISAs (UK) will always detect a material misstatement when it exists. Misstatements can arise from fraud or error and are considered material if, individually or in the aggregate, they could reasonably be expected to influence the economic decisions of users taken on the basis of these financial statements.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>The extent to which our procedures are capable of detecting irregularities, including fraud is detailed below: </div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div><div>
<div>Irregularities, including fraud, are instances of non-compliance with laws and regulations. We design procedures in line with our responsibilities, outlined above, to detect material misstatements in respect of irregularities, including fraud.</div>
<div>In identifying and assessing the risks of material misstatements in respect of irregularities, including fraud and non- compliance with laws and regulations we considered the nature of the company and the industry and the company's control environment. We identified specific laws and regulations which we considered may have a direct material effect on the financial statements or the operation of the company such as the Companies Act 2006, taxation legislation, employment laws and health and safety regulations. We assessed the extent of compliance with laws and regulations identified through making inquiries of management and discussing their policies and procedures regarding compliance with laws and regulations, inspecting correspondence, if any, with relevant licensing or regulatory authorities.</div>
<div>We evaluated the directors and management's incentives and opportunities for fraudulent manipulation of the financial statements, including the risk of management bias and override of controls. Our audit procedures to respond to the risks identified included but not limited to the following:</div>
<ul>
<li>Performing analytical procedures to identify any unusual or unexpected relationships and testing appropriateness of journal entries and other adjustments.</li>
<li>Assessing whether judgements and assumptions made in determining accounting estimates were indicative of potential bias; and evaluating business rationale of any significant transactions that are unusual or outside the normal course of business.</li>
<li>Evaluating the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of accounting estimates and related disclosures made by the directors.</li>
<li>Evaluating the overall presentation, structure and content of the financial statements, including the disclosures, and whether the financial statements represent the underlying transactions and events in a manner that achieves fair presentation.</li>
<li>Obtaining sufficient appropriate audit evidence regarding the financial information of the entities or business activities within the company to express an opinion on the financial statements. We are responsible for the direction, supervision and performance of the company audit. We remain solely responsible for our audit opinion.</li>
</ul>
<div>Identified laws and regulations and potential fraud risks were communicated to all engagement team member and remained alert to any indications of fraud or non-compliance with laws and regulations throughout the audit.</div>
<div>There are inherent limitations in the audit procedures described above and the primary responsibility for the prevention and detection of irregularities including fraud rests with management. As with any audit, there remained a risk of non-detection of irregularities, as these may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omissions, misrepresentations or the override of internal controls.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
</div></div>
<div>A further description of our responsibilities for the audit of the financial statements is located on the Financial Reporting Council's website www.frc.org.uk/auditorsresponsibilities. This description forms part of our auditor's report.</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>This report is made solely to the company's members, as a body, in accordance with Chapter 3 of Part 16 of the Companies Act 2006. Our audit work has been undertaken so that we might state to the company's members those matters that we are required to state to them in an auditor's report and for no other purpose. To the fullest extent permitted by law, we do not accept or assume responsibility to anyone other than the company and the company's members as a body, for our audit work, for this report, or for the opinions we have formed.</div>
</div>

<div class="sectionName">Notes to the Financial Statements</div>
<div class="note-section" id="p_notes">
<div class="counted" id="generalInformationFRS102Id">
<span class="counterPrefix">1.</span>
<span class="title">General Information</span>
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div><span>
<ix:nonNumeric contextRef="CURRENT_FY_PERIOD" name="frs-bus:EntityCurrentLegalOrRegisteredName">United Wholesale Grocers Limited</ix:nonNumeric>
</span> is a private company, limited by shares, incorporated in Scotland, registered number <span>
<ix:nonNumeric contextRef="CURRENT_FY_PERIOD" name="frs-bus:UKCompaniesHouseRegisteredNumber">SC080027</ix:nonNumeric>
</span>. The registered office is 246 Flemington Street, Glasgow, G21 4BY.</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="counted" id="statementOfComplianceId">
<span class="counterPrefix">2.</span>
<span class="title">Statement of Compliance</span>
<div>
<ix:nonNumeric contextRef="CURRENT_FY_PERIOD" name="frs-core:StatementComplianceWithApplicableReportingFramework">
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>The financial statements have been prepared in accordance with Financial Reporting Standard 102 "The Financial Reporting Standard applicable in the UK and Republic of Ireland" and the Companies Act 2006.</div>
</div>
</ix:nonNumeric>
</div>
</div>
<div class="counted" id="p5_6_Accounting_Policies">
<span class="counterPrefix">3.</span>
<span class="title">Accounting Policies</span>
<div class="note-section">
<div class="counted" id="p5_6_1_Basis_of_preparation_of_financial_statements">
<span class="counterPrefix">3.1.</span>
<span class="title">Basis of Preparation of Financial Statements</span>
<div>
<ix:nonNumeric contextRef="CURRENT_FY_PERIOD" name="frs-core:GeneralDescriptionBasisMeasurementUsedInPreparingFinancialStatements">
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>The financial statements have been prepared under the historical cost convention.</div>
</div>
</ix:nonNumeric>
</div>
</div>
<div class="counted" id="ReduceDisclosureExemptions_openingText">
<span class="counterPrefix">3.2.</span>
<span class="title">Financial Reporting Standard 102 - Reduced Disclosure Exemptions</span>
<div>
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>The company has taken advantage of the following disclosure exemptions in preparing these financial statements, as permitted by FRS 102 "The Financial Reporting Standard applicable in the UK and Republic of Ireland":</div>
</div>
</div>
<ul class="notesMarkedList">
<li id="ReduceDisclosureExemptions_cashFlow">
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>the requirements of Section 7 Statement of Cash Flows and Section 3 Financial Statement Presentation paragraph 3.17 (d).</div>
</div>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="counted" id="p5_6_Going_Concern_Disclosure">
<span class="counterPrefix">3.3.</span>
<span class="title">Going Concern Disclosure</span>
<div>
<ix:nonNumeric contextRef="CURRENT_FY_PERIOD" name="frs-core:DescriptionGoing-concernStatus">
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>The directors have not identified any material uncertainties related to events or conditions that may cast significant doubt about the company's ability to continue as a going concern. Accordingly, they continue to adopt the going concern basis in preparing the Company financial statements.</div>
</div>
</ix:nonNumeric>
</div>
</div>
<div class="counted" id="p5_6_Significant_Judgements_and_Estimations">
<span class="counterPrefix">3.4.</span>
<span class="title">Significant judgements and estimations</span>
<div>
<ix:nonNumeric contextRef="CURRENT_FY_PERIOD" name="frs-core:GeneralDescriptionCriticalEstimatesJudgements">
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>The preparation of accounts in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles requires the Directors to make judgements, estimates and assumptions that affect the application of policies and reported amounts of assets and liabilities, income and expenses. The estimates and associated assumptions are based on historical experience and other factors that are relevant. Actual results may differ from these estimates. The estimates and underlying assumptions are reviewed on an ongoing basis. Revisions to accounting estimates are recognised in the period in which the estimate is revised.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>In preparing these financial statements, the directors have made the following judgements:</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>Tangible fixed assets, other than investment properties, are depreciated over their useful lives taking into account residual values, where appropriate. The actual lives of the assets and residual values are assessed annually and may vary depending on a number of factors. In re-assessing asset lives, factors such as technological innovation, product life cycles and maintenance programmes are taken into account. Residual value assessments consider issues such as future market conditions, the remaining life of the asset and projected disposal values.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>Investment properties are valued each year. The directors consider market conditions and the value of similar property in deciding a fair value.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>Bad debts are provided for where objective evidence of the need for a provision exists.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>Stocks are assessed for evidence of obsolescence and a provision is made against any inventory unlikely to be sold.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
</div>
</ix:nonNumeric>
</div>
</div>
<div class="pageElement" style="padding-top: 17.16px;">
<div class="break">
<div class="pagWebviewPageFooter">Page 15</div>
</div>
<div class="pagPrintPageFooter" style="top: 998.16px;">Page 16</div>
</div>
<div class="pageHeader underline">
<div>United Wholesale Grocers Limited</div>
<div>Notes to the Financial Statements (continued)</div>
<div><span>For The Year Ended 31 December 2023</span>
</div>
</div>
<div class="counted" id="p5_6_3_Turnover">
<span class="counterPrefix">3.5.</span>
<span class="title">Turnover</span>
<div>
<ix:nonNumeric contextRef="CURRENT_FY_PERIOD" name="frs-core:RevenueRecognitionPolicy">
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>Turnover comprises revenue recognised when goods are received by the customers and risks and rewards of ownership passed to them. Revenue represents amounts receivable for goods and services net of Value Added Tax and trade discounts.</div>
</div>
</ix:nonNumeric>
</div>
</div>
<div class="counted" id="p5_6_4_Tangible_fixed_assets_and_depreciation">
<span class="counterPrefix">3.6.</span>
<span class="title">Tangible Fixed Assets and Depreciation </span>
<div>
<ix:nonNumeric contextRef="CURRENT_FY_PERIOD" name="frs-core:PropertyPlantEquipmentPolicy">
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>Tangible fixed assets under the cost model, other than investment properties, are stated in the statement of financial position at historical cost, except use of GAAP value of land and buildings on 1 January 2014 as deemed cost, less any subsequent accumulated depreciation and subsequent accumulated impairment losses. </div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>The cost of tangible assets includes directly attributable incremental costs incurred in their acquisition and installation.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>Depreciation is provided at rates calculated to write off the cost of the fixed assets, less their estimated residual value, over their expected useful lives on the following bases:</div>
</div>
</ix:nonNumeric>
</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<table style="padding-left:2em; width: 100%">
<tr>
<td class="text" style="width: 250px" title="FH_Land_Header">Freehold</td>
<td class="text" title="FH_Land_Policy">
<span>
<ix:nonNumeric contextRef="CURRENT_FY_PERIOD_LandBuildings_Freehold" name="frs-core:DescriptionDepreciationMethodForPropertyPlantEquipment">50 years</ix:nonNumeric>
</span>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="text" style="width: 250px" title="Plant_Eq_Header">Plant & Machinery</td>
<td class="text" title="Plant_Eq_Policy">
<span>
<ix:nonNumeric contextRef="CURRENT_FY_PERIOD_PlantMachinery" name="frs-core:DescriptionDepreciationMethodForPropertyPlantEquipment">5 to 7 years</ix:nonNumeric>
</span>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="text" style="width: 250px" title="Motor_Vehicles_Header">Motor Vehicles</td>
<td class="text" title="Motor_Vehicles_Policy">
<span>
<ix:nonNumeric contextRef="CURRENT_FY_PERIOD_MotorVehicles" name="frs-core:DescriptionDepreciationMethodForPropertyPlantEquipment">5 years</ix:nonNumeric>
</span>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>
<div class="counted" id="p5_6_4_1Investment_Properties">
<span class="counterPrefix">3.7.</span>
<span class="title">Investment Properties</span>
<div>
<ix:nonNumeric contextRef="CURRENT_FY_PERIOD" name="frs-core:InvestmentPropertyPolicy">
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>All investment properties are carried at fair value determined annually and derived from the current market rents and investment property yields for comparable real estate, adjusted if necessary for any difference in the nature, location or condition of the specific asset. No depreciation is provided for. Changes in fair value are recognised in the profit and loss account.</div>
</div>
</ix:nonNumeric>
</div>
</div>
<div class="counted" id="p5_6_4_2Investment_Fixed_Assets">
<span class="counterPrefix">3.8.</span>
<span class="title">Investments</span>
<div>
<ix:nonNumeric contextRef="CURRENT_FY_PERIOD" name="frs-core:FixedAssetsInvestmentPolicy">
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>Investments in quoted and unquoted shares are initially stated at cost and subsequently at a fair value. Changes in fair value are recognised in profit or loss.</div>
</div>
</ix:nonNumeric>
</div>
</div>
<div class="counted" id="p5_6_5_Leasing_and_Hire_Purchase_contracts">
<span class="counterPrefix">3.9.</span>
<span class="title">Leasing and Hire Purchase Contracts</span>
<div>
<ix:nonNumeric contextRef="CURRENT_FY_PERIOD" name="frs-core:LeasesPolicy">
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>Assets obtained under finance leases are capitalised as tangible fixed assets. Assets acquired under finance leases are depreciated over the shorter of the lease term and their useful lives. Assets acquired under hire purchase contracts are depreciated over their useful lives.  Finance leases are those where substantially all of the benefits and risks of ownership are assumed by the company.  Obligations under such agreements are included in the creditors net of the finance charge allocated to future periods. The finance element of the rental payment is charged to the profit and loss account so as to produce a constant periodic rate of charge on the net obligation outstanding in each period.</div>
<br/>
<div>Rentals applicable to operating leases where substantially all of the benefits and risks of ownership remain with the lessor are charged to profit and loss account as incurred.</div>
</div>
</ix:nonNumeric>
</div>
</div>
<div class="counted" id="p5_6_6_Stocks_and_work_in_progress">
<span class="counterPrefix">3.10.</span>
<span class="title">Stocks and Work in Progress</span>
<div>
<ix:nonNumeric contextRef="CURRENT_FY_PERIOD" name="frs-core:InventoriesPolicy">
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>Stocks are stated at the lower of cost and estimated selling price less costs to complete and sell. Cost is determined using the weighted average method. Costs of purchased stock are determined after deducting rebates and discounts. A provision is made for obsolete and slow-moving items. </div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>At each reporting date, stocks are assessed for impairment. If stocks are impaired, the carrying amount is reduced to its selling price less costs to complete and sell; the impairment loss is recognised immediately in profit or loss.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
</div>
</ix:nonNumeric>
</div>
</div>
<div class="pageElement" style="padding-top: 3.16px;">
<div class="break">
<div class="pagWebviewPageFooter">Page 16</div>
</div>
<div class="pagPrintPageFooter" style="top: 998.16px;">Page 17</div>
</div>
<div class="pageHeader underline">
<div>United Wholesale Grocers Limited</div>
<div>Notes to the Financial Statements (continued)</div>
<div><span>For The Year Ended 31 December 2023</span>
</div>
</div>
<div class="counted" id="p5_6_6a_Cash_And_Cash_Equivalents">
<span class="counterPrefix">3.11.</span>
<span class="title">Cash and Cash Equivalents</span>
<div>
<ix:nonNumeric contextRef="CURRENT_FY_PERIOD" name="frs-core:CashCashEquivalentsPolicy">
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>Cash and cash equivalents comprise cash on hand and call deposits, and other short-term highly liquid investments that are readily convertible to a known amount of cash and are subject to an insignificant risk of change in value.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
</div>
</ix:nonNumeric>
</div>
</div>
<div class="counted" id="p5_6_6b_Financial_instruments">
<span class="counterPrefix">3.12.</span>
<span class="title">Financial Instruments</span>
<div>
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>Classification</div>
<div>Financial instruments are classified and accounted for, according to the substance of the contractual arrangement, as either financial assets, financial liabilities or equity instruments. An equity instrument is any contract that evidences a residual interest in the assets of the company after deducting all of its liabilities.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>Recognition and measurement</div>
<div>Debt instruments (other than those wholly repayable or receivable within one year), including loans and other accounts receivable and payable, are initially measured at present value of the future cash flows and subsequently at amortised cost using the effective interest method. Debt instruments that are payable or receivable within one year, typically trade payables or receivables, are measured, initially and subsequently, at the undiscounted amount of the cash or other consideration, expected to be paid or received. However if the arrangement of a short-term instrument constitute a financing transaction, like the payment of a trade debt deferred beyond normal business terms or financed at a rate of interest that is not a market rate or in case of an out-right short-term loan not at a market rate, the financial asset or liability is measured, initially at the present value of the future cash flow discounted at a market rate of interest for a similar debt instrument and subsequently at a amortised cost. </div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>Financial asset that are measured at cost and amortised cost are assessed at the end of each reporting period for objective evidence of impairment. If objective evidence of impairment is found, an impairment loss is recognised in the Statement of Income.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>For financial assets measured at amortised cost, the impairment loss is measured as the difference between asset's carrying amount and the present value of estimated cash flows discounted at the asset's original effective interest rate. If a financial asset has a variable interest rate, the discount rate for measuring any impairment loss is current effective interest rate determined under the contract.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>For financial assets measured at cost less impairment, the impairment loss is measured as the difference between an asset's carrying amount and best estimate, which is an approximation of the amount that the Company would receive for the asset if it were to be sold at the balance sheet date.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>Financial assets and liabilities are offset, and the net amount reported in the Balance Sheet when there is an enforceable right to set off the recognised amounts and there is an intention to settle on a net basis or to realise the asset and settle the liability simultaneously.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="counted" id="p5_6_7_Foreign_currencies">
<span class="counterPrefix">3.13.</span>
<span class="title">Foreign Currencies</span>
<div>
<ix:nonNumeric contextRef="CURRENT_FY_PERIOD" name="frs-core:ForeignCurrencyTranslationOperationsPolicy">
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>Monetary assets and liabilities in foreign currencies are translated into sterling at the rates of exchange ruling at the balance sheet date.  Transactions in foreign currencies are translated into sterling at the rate ruling on the date of the transaction.  Exchange differences are taken into account in arriving at the operating profit.</div>
</div>
</ix:nonNumeric>
</div>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>
<div class="counted" id="p5_6_8_Deferred_taxation">
<span class="counterPrefix">3.14.</span>
<span class="title">Taxation</span>
<div>
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>Income tax expense represents the sum of the tax currently payable and deferred tax.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>The tax currently payable is based on taxable profit for the year. Taxable profit differs from profit as reported in the statement of comprehensive income because of items of income or expense that are taxable or deductible in other years and items that are never taxable or deductible. The company's liability for current tax is calculated using tax rates that have been enacted or substantively enacted by the end of the reporting period.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>Deferred tax is recognised on timing differences between the carrying amounts of assets and liabilities in the financial statements and the corresponding tax bases used in the computation of taxable profit. Deferred tax liabilities are generally recognised for all taxable timing differences. Deferred tax assets are generally recognised for all deductible temporary differences to the extent that it is probable that taxable profits will be available against which those deductible timing differences can be utilised. The carrying amount of deferred tax assets is reviewed at the end of each reporting period and reduced to the extent that it is no longer probable that sufficient taxable profits will be available to allow all or part of the asset to be recovered.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured at the tax rates that are expected to apply in the period in which the liability is settled or the asset realised, based on tax rates (and tax laws) that have been enacted or substantively enacted by the end of the reporting period. Deferred tax liabilities are presented within provisions for liabilities and deferred tax assets within debtors. The measurement of deferred tax liabilities and assets reflect the tax consequences that would follow from the manner in which the Company expects, at the end of the reporting period, to recover or settle the carrying amount of its assets and liabilities.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>Current or deferred tax for the year is recognised in profit or loss, except when they related to items that are recognised in other comprehensive income or directly in equity, in which case, the current and deferred tax is also recognised in other comprehensive income or directly in equity respectively.</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="counted" id="p5_6_8_0_ProvisionsContingencies">
<span class="counterPrefix">3.15.</span>
<span class="title">Provisions and Contingencies</span>
<div>
<ix:nonNumeric contextRef="CURRENT_FY_PERIOD" name="frs-core:ProvisionsPolicy">
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>
<span style=" font-weight:bold;">Provisions</span>
</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>Provisions are recognised when the company has a present legal or constructive obligation as a result of past events; it is probable that an outflow of resources will be required to settle the obligation; and the amount of the obligation can be estimated reliably.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>
<span style=" font-weight:bold;">Contingencies</span>
</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>Contingent liabilities are not recognised. Contingent liabilities arise as a result of past events when (i) it is not probable that there will be an outflow of resources or that the amount cannot be reliably measured at the reporting date or (ii) when the existence will be confirmed by the occurrence or non-occurrence of uncertain future events not wholly within the company’s control. Contingent liabilities are disclosed in the financial statements unless the probability of an outflow of resources is remote.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>Contingent assets are not recognised. Contingent assets are disclosed in the financial statements when an inflow of economic benefits is probable.</div>
</div>
</ix:nonNumeric>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<ix:nonNumeric contextRef="CURRENT_FY_PERIOD" name="frs-core:ProvisionsFree-textComment">
<div class="noteTextBlock">
<div>
<span style=" font-weight:bold;">Other provisions</span>
</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
<div>In 2013 the company purchased certain goods from a supplier at a market price inclusive of excise duty. HM Revenue and Customs allege that the UK duty on the goods was not paid by the defaulting/missing trader or supplier, therefore any person involved in the holding of the excise goods is jointly and severally liable to pay the duty. Hence HM Revenue & Customs has raised an assessment for unpaid duty amounting to £713,992. The company lodged an appeal against the assessment awaiting hearing. Based on legal advice management believes that the defence against the assessment will be successful. Although liability is not admitted but because of uncertainty, a full provision has been made.</div>
<div class="blank-line"/>
</div>
</ix:nonNumeric>
<div class="blank-line"/>
</div>

2022-12-31 Registered number: SC080027 United Wholesale Grocers Limited Strategic Report, Directors' Report and Financial Statements For The Year Ended 31 December 2023 United Wholesale Grocers Limited Contents Contents Page Strategic Report 1—3 Directors' Report 4—6 Independent Auditor's Report 7—10 Statement of Comprehensive Income 11 Balance Sheet 12—13 Statement of Changes in Equity 14 Notes to the Financial Statements 15—25 Page 1 United Wholesale Grocers Limited Strategic Report For The Year Ended 31 December 2023 Strategic Report The directors present their strategic report for the year ended 31 December 2023. Review of the Business The company's performance in 2023 reflects solid growth and prudent financial management, with key highlights across both financial and non-financial metrics. Financial Performance: Revenue Growth: The company achieved a 3.81% increase in turnover, reaching £226.3 million, up from £218 million in 2022. This steady growth is attributed to effective product availability management, particularly through strategic stockpiling when shortages were anticipated, positively impacting sales performance. Profitability: Gross profit rose to £18.8 million, an increase of £1.9 million from the previous year, driven by improved purchasing discounts and a well-calibrated pricing and promotional strategy. Operating profit saw an even more pronounced rise, growing by 27.2% to £6.1 million from £4.8 million. This impressive growth is largely due to enhanced gross margins and disciplined cost management, keeping operating expenses below inflation levels. Cash Reserves: The company’s cash generation has been robust, with cash and cash equivalents increasing to £20.7 million from £19.1 million in 2022. This healthy liquidity positions the company strongly, providing financial flexibility and headroom for future investments and mitigating external economic uncertainties.The company's turnover increased by 3.81% to £226.3 million from £218 million in 2022. We have continued to improve and manage availability of products during this period and where shortage was expected we carried higher level of stock, which resulted in the favourable impact on sales. Non-Financial Performance The company closely monitors key non-financial indicators such as customer satisfaction, staff turnover, and stakeholder relationships. These metrics are vital in maintaining a positive company culture, strong customer loyalty, and solid relationships with suppliers and other stakeholders. Regular feedback is gathered to continuously improve these areas. Principal Risks and Uncertainties The Board has implemented internal controls to facilitate the identification, assessment and management of risk, as a reasonable assurance against adverse implications. The principal risks determined by the Board, corresponding controls and mitigation actions are set out below and is not in particular order of priority. This represents the company's current profile and is not intended to be an exhaustive list of risks and uncertainties that may arise. Regulatory Compliance: The business operates in a highly regulated environment, covering areas such as health and safety, employment law, and data protection. The board is vigilant about regulatory changes, regularly updating policies and ensuring relevant employee training to maintain compliance. Failure to do so could harm profitability and reputation. Competition: The wholesale industry remains intensely competitive, with pressure from both national retailers and regional independent wholesalers. The company competes effectively through a combination of competitive pricing, strong value propositions, and attractive promotions, ensuring it remains responsive to market shifts. Post-Brexit Effects: The company capitalized on Brexit by strategically holding higher stock levels, which bolstered sales. However, this benefit is unlikely to recur, and future profit margins may face pressure as the market adjusts to new conditions. Interest Rate Fluctuations : The company has benefited from the current high interest rates, but a potential reduction, as predicted, could impact profitability. Proactive financial planning will be necessary to mitigate this risk. Supplier Relationships and Credit Risk : Maintaining strong supplier relationships is critical to ensuring product availability. Any disruption in supply or reduction in supplier credit could adversely affect operations. The company mitigates this by closely managing supplier performance and maintaining diverse sourcing channels. ...CONTINUED Page 1 Page 2 United Wholesale Grocers Limited Strategic Report (continued) For The Year Ended 31 December 2023 Principal Risks and Uncertainties - continued Mitigation Strategies: Credit Risk Management: The company conducts stringent credit checks on new customers and employs robust credit control procedures. Additionally, it secures guarantees or undertakings from customers to safeguard against defaults. Operational Resilience: IT systems are essential for business continuity, and the company has invested in comprehensive backup procedures, network security, and independent cybersecurity expertise. This mitigates risks related to system failures and cyber threats. Health and Safety: The company prioritizes workplace safety, ensuring compliance with regulatory standards to avoid incidents that could result in financial or reputational damage. Policies and procedures are regularly reviewed and enforced across the business. Future Developments The company is well-positioned for future growth, with the directors intending to build on the strategies that have driven consistent performance. While inflationary pressures and broader economic uncertainties remain, the company’s strong cash reserves provide a solid foundation for investment in new sales outlets and other growth opportunities. The management team is aware of the challenges ahead, including competitive pressures and the normalization of post-COVID market dynamics, but remains confident in the resilience of the business model. Strategic investments and continued focus on operational efficiency will be crucial in driving sustainable growth. While we remain cautious about the current economic climate, we hope to demonstrate the strength of our business model with the continued support of our employees a successful relationship with our suppliers and customers. Page 2 Page 3 United Wholesale Grocers Limited Strategic Report (continued) For The Year Ended 31 December 2023 Section 172(1) Statement The directors are committed to promote the success of the company, and in doing so, complying with their duties under Section 172 of the Companies Act 2006. In doing this, the directors have given careful considerations to the following factors: - the likely consequences of any decision in the long-terms; - the interest of company's employees; - the need to foster the company's relationship; - the impact of the company's operations on the community and the environment; - the desirability of the company's maintaining a reputation for high standards of business conduct: and - the need to act fairly as between members of the company The directors have also considered the company's business activities to identify the company's key stakeholders, which includes the following: - Employees - Shareholders - Suppliers, insurers and contractors - Customers - Local communities and the environment - Government and regulatory authorities The Board is committed to effective engagement with all of its stakeholders. The relevance of each stakeholder group may differ and, as such, as part of its engagement with stakeholders, the board understands the relative interests and priority of each relevant stakeholder group and have regard to these, as appropriate, in its decision making. The board acknowledges that not every decision it makes will necessarily result in a positive outcome for all stakeholder groups, however, they consider this as part of wider consideration of all stakeholder group for effective decision making. Every month, the Board and management team undertakes a review where they discuss the financial and strategic performance of the company and the impact of significant decisions taken in the period. The aim is to identify factors which would lead to any positive or negative impact, financial and non-financial, on the status of the company's stakeholders including its employees, shareholders, suppliers, customers, communities, the environment, regulators and the government. The Board and its management team regularly share reports on issues concerning employees, shareholders, customers, suppliers, insurance, contractors, communities, the environment, regulators and the government, which takes into account in its discussion and in its decision- making process under section 172. Also, the Board seeks to understand interests and views of the stakeholders and engage with them directly as appropriate. The risk management framework and principal risks and uncertainties are stated as set out above. Statement of Compliance The financial statements have been prepared in accordance with Financial Reporting Standard 102 "The Financial Reporting Standard applicable in the UK and Republic of Ireland" and the Companies Act 2006. 3. Accounting Policies 3.1. Basis of Preparation of Financial Statements The financial statements have been prepared under the historical cost convention. 3.2. Financial Reporting Standard 102 - Reduced Disclosure Exemptions The company has taken advantage of the following disclosure exemptions in preparing these financial statements, as permitted by FRS 102 "The Financial Reporting Standard applicable in the UK and Republic of Ireland": the requirements of Section 7 Statement of Cash Flows and Section 3 Financial Statement Presentation paragraph 3.17 (d). 3.3. Going Concern Disclosure The directors have not identified any material uncertainties related to events or conditions that may cast significant doubt about the company's ability to continue as a going concern. Accordingly, they continue to adopt the going concern basis in preparing the Company financial statements. 3.4. Significant judgements and estimations The preparation of accounts in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles requires the Directors to make judgements, estimates and assumptions that affect the application of policies and reported amounts of assets and liabilities, income and expenses. The estimates and associated assumptions are based on historical experience and other factors that are relevant. Actual results may differ from these estimates. The estimates and underlying assumptions are reviewed on an ongoing basis. Revisions to accounting estimates are recognised in the period in which the estimate is revised. In preparing these financial statements, the directors have made the following judgements: Tangible fixed assets, other than investment properties, are depreciated over their useful lives taking into account residual values, where appropriate. The actual lives of the assets and residual values are assessed annually and may vary depending on a number of factors. In re-assessing asset lives, factors such as technological innovation, product life cycles and maintenance programmes are taken into account. Residual value assessments consider issues such as future market conditions, the remaining life of the asset and projected disposal values. Investment properties are valued each year. The directors consider market conditions and the value of similar property in deciding a fair value. Bad debts are provided for where objective evidence of the need for a provision exists. Stocks are assessed for evidence of obsolescence and a provision is made against any inventory unlikely to be sold. Page 15 Page 16 United Wholesale Grocers Limited Notes to the Financial Statements (continued) For The Year Ended 31 December 2023 3.5. Turnover Turnover comprises revenue recognised when goods are received by the customers and risks and rewards of ownership passed to them. Revenue represents amounts receivable for goods and services net of Value Added Tax and trade discounts. 3.6. Tangible Fixed Assets and Depreciation Tangible fixed assets under the cost model, other than investment properties, are stated in the statement of financial position at historical cost, except use of GAAP value of land and buildings on 1 January 2014 as deemed cost, less any subsequent accumulated depreciation and subsequent accumulated impairment losses. The cost of tangible assets includes directly attributable incremental costs incurred in their acquisition and installation. Depreciation is provided at rates calculated to write off the cost of the fixed assets, less their estimated residual value, over their expected useful lives on the following bases: Freehold 50 years Plant & Machinery 5 to 7 years Motor Vehicles 5 years 3.7. Investment Properties All investment properties are carried at fair value determined annually and derived from the current market rents and investment property yields for comparable real estate, adjusted if necessary for any difference in the nature, location or condition of the specific asset. No depreciation is provided for. Changes in fair value are recognised in the profit and loss account. 3.8. Investments Investments in quoted and unquoted shares are initially stated at cost and subsequently at a fair value. Changes in fair value are recognised in profit or loss. 3.9. Leasing and Hire Purchase Contracts Assets obtained under finance leases are capitalised as tangible fixed assets. Assets acquired under finance leases are depreciated over the shorter of the lease term and their useful lives. Assets acquired under hire purchase contracts are depreciated over their useful lives. Finance leases are those where substantially all of the benefits and risks of ownership are assumed by the company. Obligations under such agreements are included in the creditors net of the finance charge allocated to future periods. The finance element of the rental payment is charged to the profit and loss account so as to produce a constant periodic rate of charge on the net obligation outstanding in each period. Rentals applicable to operating leases where substantially all of the benefits and risks of ownership remain with the lessor are charged to profit and loss account as incurred. 3.10. Stocks and Work in Progress Stocks are stated at the lower of cost and estimated selling price less costs to complete and sell. Cost is determined using the weighted average method. Costs of purchased stock are determined after deducting rebates and discounts. A provision is made for obsolete and slow-moving items. At each reporting date, stocks are assessed for impairment. If stocks are impaired, the carrying amount is reduced to its selling price less costs to complete and sell; the impairment loss is recognised immediately in profit or loss. Page 16 Page 17 United Wholesale Grocers Limited Notes to the Financial Statements (continued) For The Year Ended 31 December 2023 3.11. Cash and Cash Equivalents Cash and cash equivalents comprise cash on hand and call deposits, and other short-term highly liquid investments that are readily convertible to a known amount of cash and are subject to an insignificant risk of change in value. 3.12. Financial Instruments Classification Financial instruments are classified and accounted for, according to the substance of the contractual arrangement, as either financial assets, financial liabilities or equity instruments. An equity instrument is any contract that evidences a residual interest in the assets of the company after deducting all of its liabilities. Recognition and measurement Debt instruments (other than those wholly repayable or receivable within one year), including loans and other accounts receivable and payable, are initially measured at present value of the future cash flows and subsequently at amortised cost using the effective interest method. Debt instruments that are payable or receivable within one year, typically trade payables or receivables, are measured, initially and subsequently, at the undiscounted amount of the cash or other consideration, expected to be paid or received. However if the arrangement of a short-term instrument constitute a financing transaction, like the payment of a trade debt deferred beyond normal business terms or financed at a rate of interest that is not a market rate or in case of an out-right short-term loan not at a market rate, the financial asset or liability is measured, initially at the present value of the future cash flow discounted at a market rate of interest for a similar debt instrument and subsequently at a amortised cost. Financial asset that are measured at cost and amortised cost are assessed at the end of each reporting period for objective evidence of impairment. If objective evidence of impairment is found, an impairment loss is recognised in the Statement of Income. For financial assets measured at amortised cost, the impairment loss is measured as the difference between asset's carrying amount and the present value of estimated cash flows discounted at the asset's original effective interest rate. If a financial asset has a variable interest rate, the discount rate for measuring any impairment loss is current effective interest rate determined under the contract. For financial assets measured at cost less impairment, the impairment loss is measured as the difference between an asset's carrying amount and best estimate, which is an approximation of the amount that the Company would receive for the asset if it were to be sold at the balance sheet date. Financial assets and liabilities are offset, and the net amount reported in the Balance Sheet when there is an enforceable right to set off the recognised amounts and there is an intention to settle on a net basis or to realise the asset and settle the liability simultaneously. 3.13. Foreign Currencies Monetary assets and liabilities in foreign currencies are translated into sterling at the rates of exchange ruling at the balance sheet date. Transactions in foreign currencies are translated into sterling at the rate ruling on the date of the transaction. Exchange differences are taken into account in arriving at the operating profit. Page 17 Page 18 United Wholesale Grocers Limited Notes to the Financial Statements (continued) For The Year Ended 31 December 2023 3.14. Taxation Income tax expense represents the sum of the tax currently payable and deferred tax. The tax currently payable is based on taxable profit for the year. Taxable profit differs from profit as reported in the statement of comprehensive income because of items of income or expense that are taxable or deductible in other years and items that are never taxable or deductible. The company's liability for current tax is calculated using tax rates that have been enacted or substantively enacted by the end of the reporting period. Deferred tax is recognised on timing differences between the carrying amounts of assets and liabilities in the financial statements and the corresponding tax bases used in the computation of taxable profit. Deferred tax liabilities are generally recognised for all taxable timing differences. Deferred tax assets are generally recognised for all deductible temporary differences to the extent that it is probable that taxable profits will be available against which those deductible timing differences can be utilised. The carrying amount of deferred tax assets is reviewed at the end of each reporting period and reduced to the extent that it is no longer probable that sufficient taxable profits will be available to allow all or part of the asset to be recovered. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured at the tax rates that are expected to apply in the period in which the liability is settled or the asset realised, based on tax rates (and tax laws) that have been enacted or substantively enacted by the end of the reporting period. Deferred tax liabilities are presented within provisions for liabilities and deferred tax assets within debtors. The measurement of deferred tax liabilities and assets reflect the tax consequences that would follow from the manner in which the Company expects, at the end of the reporting period, to recover or settle the carrying amount of its assets and liabilities. Current or deferred tax for the year is recognised in profit or loss, except when they related to items that are recognised in other comprehensive income or directly in equity, in which case, the current and deferred tax is also recognised in other comprehensive income or directly in equity respectively. 3.15. Provisions and Contingencies Provisions Provisions are recognised when the company has a present legal or constructive obligation as a result of past events; it is probable that an outflow of resources will be required to settle the obligation; and the amount of the obligation can be estimated reliably. Contingencies Contingent liabilities are not recognised. Contingent liabilities arise as a result of past events when (i) it is not probable that there will be an outflow of resources or that the amount cannot be reliably measured at the reporting date or (ii) when the existence will be confirmed by the occurrence or non-occurrence of uncertain future events not wholly within the company’s control. Contingent liabilities are disclosed in the financial statements unless the probability of an outflow of resources is remote. Contingent assets are not recognised. Contingent assets are disclosed in the financial statements when an inflow of economic benefits is probable. Provisions for Liabilities Deferred Tax Other Provisions Total £ £ £ As at 1 January 2023 21,848 713,992 735,840 Deferred taxation 25,283 - 25,283 Balance at 31 December 2023 47,131 713,992 761,123 Other provisions In 2013 the company purchased certain goods from a supplier at a market price inclusive of excise duty. HM Revenue and Customs allege that the UK duty on the goods was not paid by the defaulting/missing trader or supplier, therefore any person involved in the holding of the excise goods is jointly and severally liable to pay the duty. Hence HM Revenue & Customs has raised an assessment for unpaid duty amounting to £713,992. The company lodged an appeal against the assessment awaiting hearing. Based on legal advice management believes that the defence against the assessment will be successful. Although liability is not admitted but because of uncertainty, a full provision has been made. 22. Share Capital 2023 2022 Allotted, called up but not fully paid £ £ 5,500 Ordinary Shares of £ 1 each 5,500 5,500 23. Contingent Liabilities United wholesale Grocers Ltd has a contingent bank guarantee up to £2,500,000 (2022 - £2,500,000) in favour of HM Revenue and Customs in respect of duty deferment. United Wholesale Grocers Ltd is a party, together with the other companies within the United Holdings UK Ltd Group, to a Guarantee Agreement with Clydesdale Bank plc, whereby the liabilities to Clydesdale Bank of each subsidiary are cross guaranteed by each of the companies. During the year the charge to profit or loss in respect of defined contribution schemes was £119,411 (2022: £238,874). At the balance sheet date contributions of £NIL were due to the fund and are included in creditors. 26. Dividends 2023 2022 £ £ On equity shares: Interim dividend paid 224,618 567,738 27. Ltd, a company in which a director has material interest as shareholder. Debtors include a sum of £5,000 (2022 - £58,106) due from Sans Inc.Ltd, a company in which the shareholders of United Holdings UK Ltd., the parent company, have material interest. Debtors include a sum of £121,498 (2022 - £151,446) due from RKH Barrhead Ltd, a company in which a director has material interest as a shareholder. During the year the company sold goods to RKH Barrhead Ltd amounted to £1,559,046 (2022 – £1,050,883). 28. Controlling Parties The company's immediate parent undertaking is United Holdings UK Ltd . The ultimate parent undertaking and that of the smallest and largest group for which group accounts are drawn up of which the company is a member is United Holdings UK Ltd (incorporated in Scotland). Its registered office is 246 Flemington Street, Glasgow, G21 4BY . Copies of the group accounts may be obtained from the company's registered office. Page 25
